title: Passenger sues airline after being sat next to obese man
text:
Save 
A passenger is suing an airline after claiming to have suffered back pain after being sat next to an obese man on a flight. 
James Andres Bassos reportedly said that during a flight with Etihad Airways from Sydney to Dubai, he was forced to contort his body for long periods due to the “grossly overweight” person he was sat next to. 
He told a Brisbane court that the man was spilling into his seat Telegraph Travel said, and that he was coughing frequently and had fluid coming from his mouth, according to reports by the Australian Associated Press. 
Five hours into the journey, Bassos asked if he could move seats but airline staff allegedly refused his request. Half an hour later he complained again and was reportedly moved to a crew seat. 
The court heard however that he was forced to return to his original seat later for security reasons, once for another hour and then again for the final 90 minutes of the flight. 
Bassos claims that the flight gave him a back injury, and exacerbated a pre-existing back condition. He is now seeking damages for personal injuries. 
In defence, Etihad has argued that it is not an unusual occurrence to have overweight passengers taking up extra space on a plane. However Judge Fleur Kingham said this was no reason to strike out the claim, and has now ordered Bassos to take a medical exam in Brisbane in December. 
Her reasoning also stated that she wasn’t convinced that Bassos had no chance of winning the case. 
An Etihad Airways spokesman told Telegraph Travel today: “It would be inappropriate to comment in detail on this case as legal proceedings are underway. 
“Etihad Airways will continue to oppose the action and now that Mr Bassos will finally face a medical assessment in December 2015, as directed by court, we believe that the matter will proceed to an early conclusion.”
